results.notes:
Very similar to Amanita praecox, but growing among a planted Scots pine stand (Pinus sylvestris). No hemlock present.

Small spot of reddish-brown stain (next to last photo) is interesting.

Spores (small sample from a drop) subglobose, 8-9.5 × 7-8, a few very close to being globose.

See more examples at obs 454763.

Several BLAST matches for ITS above 99%. One of these is “Amanita stranella” collected in Tennessee matched with Cover/Ident = 93/99.23. Other matches include two labeled “Amanita junquillea” from France and New Zealand. Also, one labeled “Amanita xylinivolva isolate” from Columbia.
Upon reviewing the records regarding Amanita stranella, this name is not well-supported by a useful type specimen. It’s possible that “stranella” and “xylinivolva” refer to the same taxon. Evidence currently exists that establishes A. xylinivolva as having a geographic distribution that encompasses Columbia north into Canada.

results.location_name: Sweet Valley, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Spores 8-9 x (6.5-)7-8 um, spores more or less isodiametric, (4-)5-6 angled in profile view, 5 angled in face view, 4-5 angled in polar view. Clamp connections present.

On a lawn 2-20 feet away from stand of Scotch pine.

BLAST of the edited ITS sequence produces a fairly good match with a New England collections that is labeled Entoloma sinuatum, a European species.

BLAST of the edited ITS produces matches with “Entoloma bicolor isolate” at 97.18% Ident and 96.95% each with 100% Cover. 7th down the list of hits is “Entoloma bicolor voucher” at 97.58% Ident 98% Cover.

One may wonder about the possibility that E. subsinuatum may apply here (simply based upon the name suggesting a resemblance to E. sinuatum). But, these mushrooms do not look like photos of E. subsinuatum, and BLAST matches for either this collection or the New England match did not include E. subsinuatum. A GenBank search of Entoloma subsinuatum turns up 16 sequences so named. So, the lack of matches with this species is not for lack of potential.
results.location_name: Sweet Valley, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
There’s a small patch of ground (maybe 12’ by 4’) adjacent to my property where sticks, nut husks, leaves, and other forest debris accumulates over mossy ground. Since I began paying close attention to this area (2019) I have found what I believe are examples of this same species. But, the spore morphology seems to vary considerably. For obs 367877 the spores fit well into the F. carpophilus concept. For this present observation (454765) the spores are difficult to see in the photos. This was also true of the live view through a scope. Even when Congo red was added to the mount, they do not show up very well. A small pigmented guttule is often evident, but the portion surrounding the guttule appears quite transparent and the walls seem very thin. In fact, in some cases the spore walls appear to have collapsed, eg. obs 417729 , causing the spores to appear to be considerably smaller than expected.
Spore print pale yellowish.

results.location_name: Property at 239 Golf Course Rd., Hunlock Twp., Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
These appear in the same area near the boundary of my property, but so far this year only one fruit body at a time. So, there’s not a lot of material to work with that represents a given observation. I used this one primarily to look for hymenial cystidia. I also found a few spores. Using my better scope (through which I do not get good photos) I got a decent look. Shapes vary according to profile; lacrymoid, with a single apical projection (apiculus?), smoothly sub-rhomboid, all with one gutule. Even through my better scope the contents of the spores outside the guttule (hyaline) and the walls (thin) are faint.
Cheilocystidia variously shaped, many with slightly inflated bumpy/wavy basal portion and long neck tapered to a subacute apex.

results.notes:
Small blue spot on basal context and very faint pinkish stain on stipe context (midsection) slow to develop.

Spore print brown with no olive tint. Photo is accurate.

Spores (12)16-20 x (4.5)6-7; one very small spore observed.

Damp area along a trail through beech-dominated hardwood forest, with small white pines (~3’ tall; likely planted) lining the trail (as seen in the last photo). No birch found; we specifically looked for birch. No poplar found. Except for the small pines and some maples, all the trees in the area were beech. Some shrubs/bushes present.

One fruit body collected on the hike in, and the other two on the hike out. Photos of single fruit body (posed and sectioned) taken in an open area near the lake. This same sectioned mushroom was posed near the other two, which were spotted on the hike out. Photos showing all three mushrooms taken on the side of the trail near a wood border. Photos appear to show slightly different cap colors, but I’m pretty sure this is just a function of differences in ambient lighting. Given that all three were found in the exact same habitat (probably within 100 feet) on a day very early in the season when very few mycorrhizal mushrooms were fruiting, I doubt they represent more than one species. Moreover, the habitat is unusual for Leccinum. When I sliced the mushrooms for placement into my dehydrator, I did not notice any differences in color or staining of context. Two fruit bodies preserved and stored together.
results.location_name: Lake John, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
> A group of 5 pale-capped fruiting bodies growing in close proximity to each other in two groups (2 + 3) in grass on the edge of a field next to a large red oak. Two most mature basidiomata in best shape were picked, photographed and saved.
> This collection was growing only 15 yards away from the grisette of obs 455205 (possibly A. rooseveltensis), but that was much larger mushroom with a dark gray-brown virgate cap. Interestingly, the spores of both collections are broadly-ellipsoid to ellipsoid (viewed unmounted at x400; more exact measurements TBD), suggesting they could be the same species; however, the morphology of these mushrooms suggests they are not conspecific.
> Description: The two fruiting bodies are of equal height of ~9 cm. The caps are pale cream to pale grayish-cream, with a darker brown flat to slightly depressed center, devoid of universal veil remnants, margin not appendiculate, 4.5-5 cm wide and 3-4 mm thick above the cap; the margins are prominently striate to tuberculate-striate, striations are 1.1-1.5 cm long (0.51-0.58R). The gills are white to whitish, free, 4-5 mm wide max; short gills are plentiful, of variable length and truncate. The stipes are straight, white and noticeably pulverulent for at least the upper 2/3 of length, 8.5-8.7 cm long, 6-7 mm wide at the flaring apex, 4 mm wide just below it and gradually widening to 6-7 mm in the lower stipe above the volval sack; the stipe context is white to whitish and non-staining, with a 3-4 mm wide central hollow cylinder 3-4 sparsely stuffed with a cottony-fibrous material. The volva is a thin, flexible, non-friable, wrinkled leathery sack, 1.7-2.0 cm tall (longest limb measured).

results.notes:
BECAUSE THE NORTH AMERICAN SPECIMENS HAVE A 4% DIFFERENCE IN DNA MATCHES WITH THE EUROPEAN SAMPLES, WE HAVE CHOSEN TO USE THE FOLLOWING SPECIES NAME:

Hygrocybe cf. phaeococcinea

cf. - to be compared with phaeococcinea

VOUCHER # DS-0009

DATE: 25 SEP 2020

STATE: WA

COUNTY: KITSAP

FORAY ID: Devilâs Stool Special Project, Hygrophoraceae of Lower Puget Sound

SITE NAME: 1531 SW Minterbrook Rd, Port Orchard

iNat #: 60783820

NEARBY FLORA:
Conifer: Douglas Fir, Western Red Cedar.

Deciduous: Various Trees and Plants

Evergreen: Sword Fern, Rhododendron, and various others.

SUBSTRATE: Native Grass with Thick Roots, Moss, Sandy Humous Subsoil (depth=4 cm), on top of Gravel and Rocksâ¦all Original Glacial Till.

HABIT: Many (43+ within 2â-6â area), Including a Ring with 12+ specimens within a 14â Diameter area.

LIGHT EXPOSURE: Full sun (50-60% of day)

MOISTURE: Wet, 3.8â of Rain in this Vicinity in the last Week.

AMBIENT TEMP: 60 Degrees F

SOIL TEMP: 50 Degrees F

ECOSYSTEM: Residence with extensive plants, bushes, and trees in a natural setting.

ELEVATION: 335 ft / 102 Meters

LAY OF THE LAND: Flat

ODOR: Indistinct.

TASTE: Very Pleasant, Sweet Mushroom Taste.

REFERENCE:
https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/22348499

DETAILED PHYSICAL DESCRIPTION:

CAP: Width is from .5 â 3 cm wide by 1 â 3 mm deep. Color is Deep Red/Scarlet, with slightly Orange Margins on Mature specimens. The Center is darker and slightly Umbilicate in Younger specimens becoming deeper and wider in more-mature specimens, but ultimately Flattening out in very-mature Specimens. Otherwise the shape is Convex at first, moving to Broadly Convex, and at maturity nearly flat with an Undulating Margin. The surface is dry and smooth but is slightly granulose/bumpy with older specimens. Margin is predominantly Scalloped in line with the Major Gill Ends, otherwise appearing plane or straight, particularly in younger specimens.

GILLS: Predominantly Salmon colored with Pale Yellow Edges, Sub-decurrent, Close but Unequal with many Short Gills of varying lengths. The Major Gills have a Ventricose shape and have an even/regular margin with some Erosion on Older Specimens.

STIPE: Length is significant when compared to the Cap Size, regardless of Specimen Maturity. Immature/âbabyâ specimens have a length of 2.5 cm at 1 mm width! Otherwise length gets as long as 6 cm without any association with Cap width or Specimen Age. Stipe width ranges from 2 â 5 mm, with Older Specimens being Wider. The Stipe Color is predominantly the same color as the Cap, becoming Paler, almost Translucent White at the Base. Equal, sometimes Compressed, but always with Central attachment. The Surface is Dry, and smooth w/occasional horizontally arranged âbumpinessâ at irregular intervals on some specimens. The Stipe is Hollow.

FLESH: No variation from the External Colors where cut or bruised.

SPORES: Unknown

MYCELIA: What little there appear to be, they look short and transparent. It is important to note that the Base of the Specimen ENTIRELY ENCAPSULATES Moss Fronds, so this species is either ENDOMYCORRHIZAL or SAPROPHYTIC. Which one remains undetermined until the âlivelinessâ of the Moss Frond is determined.

DNA Sequencing:

Batch Number for Ryan Schauer sample of Hygrocybe phaeococcinea is OLY-FD0107.

OLY = Olympia
(H) = Hygrophoraceae Project
FD = Fungal Diversity Survey
0107 = sequencel number

results.notes:
Definitely bitter taste, with a faint fragrant (“smelled” from chewing) undertone.
Notes on this collection from Django Grootmyers:
“Gills drying cafe au lait color. Clamps abundant in all tissues. Stipitipellis with hyaline, diverticulate and branched hyphae. Caulocystidia scattered and similar to chailocystidia. Pileus and stipe trama composed of hyaline, slightly thick-walled (sarcodimitic?) hyphae. Pileipellis a cutis composed of hyaline, branched, diverticulate and clamped hyphae. Lamellar trama inamyloid and tightly interwoven. Lactifers present in lamellar trama. Pleurocystidia abundant and similar to cheilocystidia. Cheilocystidia abundant; clavate; hyaline; smooth in Melzer’s and coated with a yellow resinous substance in NH40H; thin-walled; rarely secondarily simple-septate. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth, thin-walled and prominently apiculate. Spore measurements: (5.8) 5.9 – 7.5 (7.8) Ã (3.1) 3.6 – 4.4 (4.8) Âµm; Q = (1.5) 1.52 – 1.9 (2.1); N = 30; Me = 6.8 Ã 3.9 Âµm; Qe = 1.7”

results.notes:
A single basidiocarp growing in grass on the edge of woods near a mature read oak and a birch tree. It probably fruits there every year when conditions permit, as I previously collected A. spreta at this exact spot in early June 2016, obs 240687.
Cap footprint = 10 cm, overall height = 13 cm, stipe = 12 cm long, 8 mm wide just below apex and 1.3 cm wide max in lower stipe. Volva very crumbly, as loose chunks of tissue mixed with clay. Odor nil. Spores ellipsoid to elongate (unmounted at x400).
It was found concomitantly with A. rooseveltensis of obs 455205 (growing just 2 yards away) and Amanita sect. Vaginatae of obs 455099 (15 yards away).

results.notes:
Code: Bot_0297/2008_DSC3510
Habitat: Steep mountain slope, northwest aspect; among large boulders of a recent, large sock slide; in half shade; on sandy, calcareous ground; moderately humid place; protected from direct rain by overhanging rock; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 750 m (2.450 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: sandy soil/raw hummus, among large calcareous boulders.

Place: Bovec basin, Northwest slopes of Mt. JavorÅ¡Äek, 1557 m; toward the end of a dirt forest road, East Julian Alps, PosoÄje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Browsing literature to determine the name of this find I’ve found only one or two candidates with podetia, which sometimes proliferate in more than two stores from cup margins. Cladonia rappii as well as Cladonia cervikornis/verticilata look similarly from far, but proliferate strictly from the center of the cups. Cladonia ramulosa may look similar too, but rarely (if at all) proliferates in more than two stores and is usually fertile with numerous conspicuous brown apothecia. None of several specimens found in this observation had podetia with apothecia.

The best, although not ideal, fit I’ve found seems to be Cladonia phyllophora. All sources agree that this taxon is highly polymorphic (google the pictures of it!). The taxon is also very variously interpreted by the authors (Ref. 7.). The description in literature, which seems the closest to this find, is in Brodo, Sharnoff, Sharnoff (2001) (Ref. 2.) mentioning gradually broadening and seemingly soft near the apex podetia having a slightly puffed-up aspect and cup margins richly decorated by small and thick squamules (see Fig. 4.) and numerous brown pycnidia /see Fig.7.). The description in Smith at al (2009) (Ref. 1.) fits reasonably well too, particularly the description of the habit stated as ‘often extensive more or less interlocking tiers of proliferating podetia’. However, many sources mention that the surface of the podetia near the base should be areolate with contrasting blackened decorticated and maculated areas (Ref. 1., Ref. 8.) or blackish podetia base (Ref. 7.), which is not the case in this find. Also substratum is usually cited as acid. This find apparently grew on a mixture of sandy soil and raw hummus deposited in gaps among large rock boulders (a few meters across) of a relatively recent large mountain rock slide. It seems possible that it was at least to some extent acid, however, the bedrock and the boulders themselves are no doubt calcareous. I am not sure my determination is correct, but, I am also not aware of a better alternative.

Camera: Nikon D70 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Bovec basin, East Julian Alps, PosoÄje, Slovenia

results.notes:
A single young, yet robust, fruitbody growing in a mixed habitat. The salient features of this mushroom are the pulverulent-floccose upper stipe and large, thick “hardshell” volva with a plentiful limbus internus. Upon dissection, the stipe flesh between the central hollow/stuffed cylinder and outer cuticle reddened prominently. There was some weird damage to one side of the mushroom that included part of cap being taken over by a what looked like a mold (see photos); these areas were removed before voucher preservation).
The closest possible hosts (10 m radius) were two mature white pines, an exotic planted conifer, a tulip poplar and a 15 ft hornbeam (tree ID from photos by expert R.J. Cook of RAMA). Further out (20-25 yards) I saw several mature beech trees. This is essentially the same spot that gave rise to the Destroying Angel of obs 336720.
Identification without sequencing is going to be nearly impossible. Several taxa of sect. Amidella have been found by me at WCSP over the years, as evidenced by their DNA sequences (data to be posted eventually). Only one of these, obs 415288, has been reliably identified as A. whetstoneae by its LSU sequence.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (to be posted on 5-Apr-22):

results.notes:
Growing in mulch near the north end of the Riffe building. Odor not distinctive. Caps hygrophanous. Veil present in young basidiocarps. Gills adnexed. Stems dry. Annulus absent. Blue bruising absent on all surfaces. Cheilocystidia abundant, forming a sterile margin; hyaline and broadly lageniform. Cheilocystidia measurements: (17.4) 18.8 – 25.6 (27.2) Ã (8.8) 10.2 – 15.4 (16) Âµm, Q = (1.2) 1.5 – 2.1 (2.6); N = 30, Me = 22.3 Ã 12.6 Âµm; Qe = 1.8. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown and rhomboid or subrhomboid. Spore measurements: (6.4) 6.8 – 7.8 (8.1) Ã (4.1) 4.3 – 5 (5.1) Âµm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.7 (1.8); N = 30, Me = 7.3 Ã 4.6 Âµm; Qe = 1.6.
